Examples

Spark Beyond Package Examples


Example 1 - simple classification

Goal: Predict Titanic Passenger Survival
This example demonstrates how to perform a simple classification using the SparkBeyond platform. We will use data from the famous Kaggle competition to predict who will die on the Titanic. We can get the titanic train data by calling data = getData("titanic_train"). The column survived contains the information for whether a Titanic passenger survived. In the following example we ask the engine to create and return the top 25 features.

Data sample: 
library(xtable)
print(xtable(getData("titanic_train")[1:5,]), type='html', comment=F)
survived pclass name sex age sibsp parch ticket fare cabin embarked
1 0 3 Braund, Mr. Owen Harris male 22.00 1 0 A/5 21171 7.25 S
2 1 1 Cumings, Mrs. John Bradley (Florence Briggs Thayer) female 38.00 1 0 PC 17599 71.28 C85 C
3 1 3 Heikkinen, Miss. Laina female 26.00 0 0 STON/O2. 3101282 7.92 S
4 1 1 Futrelle, Mrs. Jacques Heath (Lily May Peel) female 35.00 1 0 113803 53.10 C123 S
5 0 3 Allen, Mr. William Henry male 35.00 0 0 373450 8.05 S 

data = getData("titanic_train")
titanicSurvivedModel = learn(projectName = "titanic_survived",
                        trainData = data,
                        target = "survived",
                        algorithmsWhiteList = list("RRandomForestClassifier"),  
                        maxFeaturesCount = 25,  # number of feature counts to check (if a list is provided
                                                # the best will be selected using cross validation)
                        scoreOnTestSet = TRUE,  # will create lift plots and prediction table 
                        autoSave = FALSE        # in order to avoid automatically creating a local object 
                                                # pointing to the created model
                    )


On the Titanic most children and women were rescued first, hence had higher survival rates. The first feature that was generated, breaks down the name column into tokens and notes that the token "mr" is not included in the passenger name. This feature effectively identifies both the children and women populations.

Here are the top 3 features (each contains a lift signal pointing to which class each feature suggests): 
print(xtable(titanicSurvivedModel$features()[1:3,c("idx", "feature", "Lift.0", "Lift.1")]), type='html', comment=F)
idx feature Lift.0 Lift.1
1 0 tokenizeByPunctuation(name) does not contain mr 0.49 1.84
2 1 pclass != 3 0.72 1.45
3 2 numberIn(ticket) in range (8854.5, 231932) 0.61 1.64

To view an html report with all the information on the features (on train or test) run: 
titanicSurvivedModel$showFeaturesTrain()
titanicSurvivedModel$showFeaturesTest()
To view the feature trace report review /reports/features/features_trace.txt:
For example, the first feature "tokenizeByPunctuation(name) does not contain mr" has a positive example trace under the "positive sample" column. The trace starts with the "name" subexpression (bottom) "Cumings, Mrs. John Bradley (Florence Briggs Thayer)", the next step of the trace is the subexpression "tokenizeByPunctuation(name)" which is directly on top of "name". It evaluates to "ArrayBuffer(cumings, mrs, john bradley, florence briggs thayer)" which does not contain "mr". The type and documentation of each subexpression function are listed in the last two columns. 
writeLines(gsub("-{2}","",readLines(paste0(titanicSurvivedModel$artifact_loc,"/reports/features/features_trace.txt"),n=9)))
## Human friendly: tokenizeByPunctuation(name) does not contain mr
## Canonical: !core.Solving.TextFunctions.tokenizeByPunctuation(name).contains("mr")
## +-+-++-++-+
## | sub-expression              | positive sample                                                 | negative sample                      | type          | root function                                                                              | reference / explanation                                                                       |
## +-+-++-++-+
## | tokenizeByPunctuation(name) | ArrayBuffer(cumings, mrs, john bradley, florence briggs thayer) | ArrayBuffer(braund, mr, owen harris) | Seq[String]   | core.Solving.TextFunctions.tokenizeByPunctuation(s: core.nlp.SemanticWrapper): Seq[String] | Returns the list of words from the text, when splitting using standard punctuation characters |
## |  name                       | Cumings, Mrs. John Bradley (Florence Briggs Thayer)             | Braund, Mr. Owen Harris              | core.nlp.Text | name                                                                                       | Input parameter 'name'                                                                        |
## +-+-++-++-+



Example 2 - simple regression

Goal: Predict Titanic Passenger
This example demonstrates how to perform a simple regression using the SparkBeyond platform. We will use the same titanic data but now we will aim to predict the column age. 
data = getData("titanic_train")
titanicAgeModel = learn(projectName = "titanic_age",
                        trainData = data,
                        target = "age",
                        algorithmsWhiteList = list("RRandomForestRegressor"),  
                        maxFeaturesCount = 25,
                        scoreOnTestSet = TRUE,
                        autoSave = FALSE
                    )

From this examples, we can see that having the tokens 'master' and 'miss' in the passenger name are strong indicators of the gender. Here are the top features: 
library(xtable)
print(xtable(titanicAgeModel$features()[1:7,c("idx", "feature")]), type='html', comment=F)
idx feature
1 0 name contains master
2 1 pclass < 3
3 2 wordFrequencies(name).valueOf(miss) orIfMissing 0.5773502691896258 < 0.5386751345948129
4 3 parch in range (0, 3.5)
5 4 fare < 9.54375
6 5 embarked == Q
7 6 stemmedWordsWithoutCommonTerms(name) does not contain mr
To view the feature trace report review /reports/features/features_trace.txt:
For example, the first feature "name contains master" has a positive example trace under the "positive sample" column. The trace starts with the "name" subexpression (bottom) "Rice, Master. Eugene", the next step of the trace is the subexpression "tokenizeByWordBoundary(name)" which is directly on top of "name". It evaluates to "Vector(rice, master, eugene)" which contains "master". The type and documentation of each subexpression function are listed in the last two columns. 
writeLines(gsub("-{2}","",readLines(paste0(titanicAgeModel$artifact_loc,"/reports/features/features_trace.txt"),n=9)))
## Human friendly: name contains master
## Canonical: core.Solving.TextFunctions.tokenizeByWordBoundary(name) contains "master"
## +++++-+-+
## | sub-expression               | positive sample              | negative sample                  | type           | root function                                                                                     | reference / explanation             |
## +++++-+-+
## | tokenizeByWordBoundary(name) | Vector(rice, master, eugene) | Vector(braund, mr, owen, harris) | Vector[String] | core.Solving.TextFunctions.tokenizeByWordBoundary(text: core.nlp.SemanticWrapper): Vector[String] | returns a list of the text\'s words |
## |  name                        | Rice, Master. Eugene         | Braund, Mr. Owen Harris          | core.nlp.Text  | name                                                                                              | Input parameter 'name'              |
## +++++-+-+



Example 3 - feature exclusion

Goal: Predict Titanic Passenger Age
This example demonstrates how to exclude elements from the generated features. Let's say that for example that for whatever reason we would prefer to not create mathematical features (such as "abs"), trigonometry features, and also exclude features that contains the word "master". We can set the functionsBlackList parameter to exclude these two terms.
Please refer to the SparkBeyond function catalog by calling functionCatalog() to view the list of functions and associated domains In this example we are using the featureSearch capability only without actually building a model. 
data = getData("titanic_train")
titanicAgeFeatures = featureSearch(projectName = "titanic_age_exclusions",
                        trainData = data,
                        target = "age", 
                        maxFeaturesCount = 10,
                        functionsBlackList = list("abs", "master", "trigonometry"),  # blacklist trigonometric functions "abs" and "master"
                        autoSave = FALSE
                    )

Note that compared to the previous example the master feature does not exist. 
library(xtable)
print(xtable(titanicAgeFeatures$features()[1:10,c("idx", "feature")]), type='html', comment=F)
idx feature
1 0 name contains master
2 1 pclass < 3
3 2 wordFrequencies(name).valueOf(miss) orIfMissing 0.5773502691896258 < 0.5386751345948129
4 3 parch in range (0, 3.5)
5 4 fare < 9.54375
6 5 embarked == Q
7 6 stemmedWordsWithoutCommonTerms(name) does not contain mr
8 7 sibsp in range (3.5, 6.5)
9 8 numberOfWords(name) < 4
10 9 sentimentDistribution(name) == Map((0, 3)) 
writeLines(readLines(paste0(titanicAgeFeatures$artifact_loc,"/reports/features/features_trace.txt"),n=9))
## Human friendly: name contains master
## Canonical: core.Solving.TextFunctions.tokenizeByWordBoundary(name) contains "master"
## +------------------------------+------------------------------+----------------------------------+----------------+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+-------------------------------------+
## | sub-expression               | positive sample              | negative sample                  | type           | root function                                                                                     | reference / explanation             |
## +------------------------------+------------------------------+----------------------------------+----------------+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+-------------------------------------+
## | tokenizeByWordBoundary(name) | Vector(rice, master, eugene) | Vector(braund, mr, owen, harris) | Vector[String] | core.Solving.TextFunctions.tokenizeByWordBoundary(text: core.nlp.SemanticWrapper): Vector[String] | returns a list of the text\'s words |
## |  name                        | Rice, Master. Eugene         | Braund, Mr. Owen Harris          | core.nlp.Text  | name                                                                                              | Input parameter 'name'              |
## +------------------------------+------------------------------+----------------------------------+----------------+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+-------------------------------------+



Example 4 - cross row search

Goal: Identify changes in density of specific rows
In this example, we will generate 500 random points in Euclidean space, and we will set as target for each point, the inverse of the minimal distance from all other points. 
n = 500
data = data.table(lat=runif(n), long = runif(n))
data[,target:=sapply(1:n, function(i) 1/min({a = (data$lat[i]-data$lat)^2+(data$long[i]-data$long)^2; a[i] = Inf;a}))]
densityModel = learn(projectName = "density_example",
                        trainData = data,
                        target = "target",
                        algorithmsWhiteList = list("RRandomForestRegressor"),  
                        crossRowFeatureSearch = TRUE,  # indicates that points from all rows should be
                                                       # considered together during feature search
                        maxFeaturesCount = 5,
                        maxDepth = 3,                               # allowing a higher search space depth
                        functionsBlackList = list("trigonometry"),  # blacklist trigonometric functions
                        autoSave = FALSE
                    )

Note that in this example:
1. While we provided the columns lat and long as two separate columns, a new feature named latLong was created that can operate in the 2D space. 2. The resulting best feature was able to capture our target by being able to generate features using the entire column information. 
library(xtable)
topFeatures = densityModel$features()[1:3,c("idx","feature")]
print(xtable(topFeatures), type='html', comment=F)
idx feature
1 0 inverse(distance of latLong from closest of latLong_column) >= 0.6940667049710194
2 1 ceil(distance of latLong from closest of latLong_column) == 2.0
3 2 ceil(distance of latLong from closest of latLong_column) == 1.0 
writeLines(readLines(paste0(densityModel$artifact_loc,"/reports/features/features_trace.txt"),n=9))
## Human friendly: inverse(distance of latLong from closest of latLong_column) >= 0.6940667049710194
## Canonical: (core.Solving.SpecialFunctions.inverse(core.common.zeroComplexity.ZeroComplexityFunctions.distanceFromClosest(core.LoadCached[scala.collection.immutable.Vector[core.datastructures.LatLong]]("/Users/zinman/localdata/artifacts/density_example/2/resources/latLong_column"), latLong))) >= 0.6940667049710194
## +--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+--------------------------------------------+----------------------------------------------+-----------------------------+-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+---------------------------+
## | sub-expression                                                                                                                                                                                         | positive sample                            | negative sample                              | type                        | root function                                                                                                                                               | reference / explanation   |

## +--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+--------------------------------------------+----------------------------------------------+-----------------------------+-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+---------------------------+



Example 5 - Sentiment analysis

Goal: Identify sentiment in twitter tweets.
### Tweets sentiment ### 
tweets = getData("tweets_sentiment")
SentimentModel = learn(projectName="tweets",
              trainData=tweets,
              target="sentiment",
              algorithmsWhiteList = list("RRandomForestClassifier"),
              maxFeaturesCount = list(50),
              evaluationMetric = "AUC",
              autoSave = FALSE)
SentimentEval = SentimentModel$evaluate()


In this example we load a sentiment dataset with a tweet column and a setiment target (-1 or 1). The top feature is a textSentimentScore which is automatically computed.

library(xtable)
print(xtable(SentimentModel$features()[1:10,c("idx","feature")]), type='html', comment=F)
idx feature
1 0 textSentimentScore(tweet) < -0.017857142857142856
2 1 sentimentDistribution(tweet).valueOf("1") orIfMissing 0 >= 0.5
3 2 slidingSubsets(tweet).toSeq contains (best, the)
4 3 tweet contains great
5 4 numberIn(tweet) == -1.0
6 5 stemmedWordsWithoutCommonTerms(tweet) contains goal
7 6 numberIn(tweet) == 1.0
8 7 tweet contains back
9 8 wordFrequencies(tweet).valueOf(shit) orIfMissing 0 >= 0.15714382244851252
10 9 tweet contains fantastic 
writeLines(gsub("\n","
",SentimentEval$evaluation$summary))
                                         <br>Correctly Classified Instances     42   84.0%<br>Incorrectly Classified Instances   8    16.0%<br>Total Number of Instances          50        <br>


### Tweets with a context database ###

sentimentLexicon = getData("sentiment_lexicon")
pathLexicon = writeToServer(sentimentLexicon)
tweets = getData("tweets_sentiment")
SentimentModelContext = learn(projectName="tweets",
              trainData=tweets,
              target="sentiment",
              algorithmsWhiteList = list("RRandomForestClassifier"),
              maxFeaturesCount = list(50),
              evaluationMetric = "AUC",
              autoSave = FALSE,
              contextDatasets = list(pathLexicon))

SentimentContextEval = SentimentModelContext$evaluate()


In order to improve performance we can include a custom context Dataset. The sentimentLexicon includes over 6000 single words with a either a positive or negative sentiment. The top features now are actually derived by looking up the values in the lexcion (data_column) and the classificaiton performance is boosted.

library(xtable)
print(xtable(SentimentModelContext$features()[1:10,c("idx","feature")]), type='html', comment=F)
idx feature
1 0 textSentimentScore(tweet) < -0.017857142857142856
2 1 sentimentDistribution(tweet).valueOf("1") orIfMissing 0 >= 0.5
3 2 slidingSubsets(tweet).toSeq contains (best, the)
4 3 tweet contains great
5 4 numberIn(tweet) == -1.0
6 5 stemmedWordsWithoutCommonTerms(tweet) contains goal
7 6 numberIn(tweet) == 1.0
8 7 tweet contains back
9 8 wordFrequencies(tweet).valueOf(shit) orIfMissing 0 >= 0.15714382244851252
10 9 tweet contains fantastic 
writeLines(gsub("\n","
",SentimentContextEval$evaluation$summary))
                                         <br>Correctly Classified Instances     42   84.0%<br>Incorrectly Classified Instances   8    16.0%<br>Total Number of Instances          50        <br>                                             
writeLines(readLines(paste0(SentimentModelContext$artifact_loc,"/reports/features/features_trace.txt"),n=9))
## Human friendly: textSentimentScore(tweet) < -0.017857142857142856
## Canonical: (core.Solving.TextFunctions.textSentimentScore(tweet)) < -0.017857142857142856

## |  tweet                    | Defensive show against Sunderland best of the season | Performance proves is far from finished | core.nlp.Text | tweet                                                                                 | Input parameter 'tweet'                                       |

Example 6 - Features combining customGraphs and weather API

Goal: Flights weather delay In this example we use data from Kaggle that contains information of flight delays caused due to weather conditions.

This example will show how airport codes (in fields origin, dest) are automatically identified as airport entities and are enriched with the corresponding latitude and longitude information of the airport. Moreover, when elements of type date and location are encountered during the feature search, external data including NOAA weather are examined for their distinctive power. The first run may take more time as weather data will be downloaded and cached. 
library(xtable)
flights = getData("flights_delay")
airports = getData("airports")
names(flights)
[1] "year" "month" "dayofMonth"
[4] "dayOfWeek" "depTime" "cRSDepTime"
[7] "arrTime" "cRSArrTime" "uniqueCarrier"
[10] "flightNum" "tailNum" "actualElapsedTime" [13] "cRSElapsedTime" "airTime" "origin"
[16] "dest" "distance" "taxiIn"
[19] "taxiOut" "cancelled" "cancellationCode" [22] "diverted" "weatherDelay" "lateAircraftDelay" [25] "date"
print(xtable(tail(airports,n=5)), type='html', comment=F) # show the airport database
Name City Country IATA ICAO Latitude Longitude Altitude Timezone DST TZ.timezone
5876 Mansons Landing Water Aerodrome Mansons Landing Canada YMU 50.07 -124.98 0 -8.00 A America/Vancouver
5877 Port McNeill Airport Port McNeill Canada YMP 50.58 -127.03 225 -8.00 A America/Vancouver
5878 Sullivan Bay Water Aerodrome Sullivan Bay Canada YTG 50.88 -126.83 0 -8.00 A America/Vancouver
5879 Deer Harbor Seaplane Deer Harbor United States DHB 48.62 -123.01 0 -8.00 A America/Los_Angeles
5880 San Diego Old Town Transit Center San Diego United States OLT 32.76 -117.20 0 -8.00 A America/Los_Angeles


The airport data will be loaded automatically as a customGraph but you could explicitly send it using contextDatasets (as in Example 5). Regardless of modality (customGraph or contextDatasets) the functionality is identical and the engine will automatically detect relevant columns in the airport data (or any other dataset) 

flightSampled = sampleDataAbsolute(flights,5000)
flightsModel = learn(projectName = "flights_delay_example",
                        trainData = flightSampled,
                        target = "weatherDelay",
                        useCustomGraphs = TRUE, 
                        algorithmsWhiteList = list("RXGBoostRegressor"),
                        functionsBlackList = list("trigonometry"),
                        maxFeaturesCount = list(30),
                        autoSave = FALSE,
                        evaluationMetric = "RMSE"
                    )
flightsModelEval = flightsModel$evaluate()


Note that in this example:

  1. For example, in the flightsModel feature 7 dataForLatLongDate(lookupGeo(dest, general_airports_csv), date) contains (VISIB, 5)the dest field is recognized as an IATA code and is enriched with geolocation data from an airport custom graph, aditionally the coordinates and date field are used to automatically download weather data and enrich with visibility data. Simillarly feature 19 assesses wind gust data at origin airport locations.

  2. Running using the entire flights data can take a long time due to the Weather API downloading approporaite data for each location (but should achieve better results). 

library(xtable)
print(xtable(flightsModel$features()[1:20,c("idx","feature")]), type='html', comment=F)
idx feature
1 0 log1p(arrTime) in range (3.569433499972762, 6.410996574838032)
2 1 taxiOut >= 50
3 2 depTime < 549
4 3 depTime not in range (548.5, 2244.5)
5 4 uniqueCarrier.min == A
6 5 date == Sun Jul 13 03:00:00 IDT 2008
7 6 uniqueCarrier == OO
8 7 sigmoid(arrTime) in range (0.9999999994813985, 0.9999999999999999)
9 8 date == Sat Mar 22 02:00:00 IST 2008
10 9 date == Fri Feb 22 02:00:00 IST 2008

writeLines(gsub("\n","
",flightsModelEval$evaluation$summary))
                                             <br>Correlation coefficient             0.971109     <br>R2                                  0.943053     <br>Mean absolute error                 9.933236     <br>Root mean squared error             17.574482    <br>Relative absolute error             20.48519378 %<br>Root relative squared error         24.61696612 %<br>Root relative prior squared error   71.39174767  <br>Actuals mean                        74.63377609  <br>Estimations mean                    72.95175912  <br>Actuals std                         71.24745501  <br>Estimations std                     65.07070017  <br>Total Number of Instances           1054         <br>                                                 
writeLines(readLines(paste0(flightsModel$artifact_loc,"/reports/features/features_trace.txt"),n=9))

Example 7 - Add custom functions

Goal: Identify numbers that are multiples of 7 You can create your own functions, which will be used as building blocks during the feature search. All you need to do, is to specify the url/s of the source files containing the custom functions code (currently only Scala is supported). The file can be local (on the server) or on the web.


data = data.frame(number = 1:500, target = 1:500 %% 7 == 0)
modModel = learn(projectName = "custom_function_example",
                        trainData = data,
                        target = "target",
                        algorithmsWhiteList = list("RRandomForestClassifier"),  
                        maxFeaturesCount = 5,                        
                        customFunctions = list("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mesagie/etcetra/master/SampleFunctions.scala"),
                        autoSave = FALSE
                    )
modModel$features()[1:1,c("idx","feature")]

idx feature 1 0 isMultipleOf7(number)





Example 9 - Deep Feature Search Google Stock


Goal: identify dependencies across variables and time series (Google Stock) 
googleStock = getData("googleStock")
print(xtable(head(googleStock,n=5)), type='html', comment=F)
date ticker open high low close volume close_sliding criticalDay happy
1 Mon Oct 05 00:00:00 EDT 2009 GOOG 487.67 492.43 483.34 488.52 21264 [465.24,468.73,471.37,468.0,466.06,464.75,461.67,455.761,453.01,457.52,461.3,463.97,470.94,472.14,475.12,477.54,488.29,491.72,491.46,497.0,499.06,498.46,496.77,492.48,498.53,498.53,495.85,487.2,484.58,488.52] 16 true
2 Tue Oct 06 00:00:00 EDT 2009 GOOG 492.37 499.37 491.70 498.74 27329 [468.73,471.37,468.0,466.06,464.75,461.67,455.761,453.01,457.52,461.3,463.97,470.94,472.14,475.12,477.54,488.29,491.72,491.46,497.0,499.06,498.46,496.77,492.48,498.53,498.53,495.85,487.2,484.58,488.52,498.74] 0 true

4 Thu Oct 08 00:00:00 EDT 2009 GOOG 519.58 523.25 513.34 514.18 43065 [468.0,466.06,464.75,461.67,455.761,453.01,457.52,461.3,463.97,470.94,472.14,475.12,477.54,488.29,491.72,491.46,497.0,499.06,498.46,496.77,492.48,498.53,498.53,495.85,487.2,484.58,488.52,498.74,517.54,514.18] 16 true
5 Fri Oct 09 00:00:00 EDT 2009 GOOG 516.43 521.51 514.50 516.25 27398 [466.06,464.75,461.67,455.761,453.01,457.52,461.3,463.97,470.94,472.14,475.12,477.54,488.29,491.72,491.46,497.0,499.06,498.46,496.77,492.48,498.53,498.53,495.85,487.2,484.58,488.52,498.74,517.54,514.18,516.25] 12 true

The target variable reflects if the google closing price today was more than the closing price at a critical time point in the past. Let's split the data sequntially and first try a regular model at depth = 2 
googleTrainTest = trainTestSplit(googleStock)

googleModel = learn(
            projectName = "googleStock",
      trainData = googleTrainTest[[1]],
      testData = googleTrainTest[[2]],
      target = "happy",
            featureGenerationCtrl = featureGenerationControl(
                    maxFeaturesCount = 50,
                    maxFeatureDuration=5
            ),
            modelBuildingCtrl = modelBuildingControl(
                    algorithmsWhiteList = list("RRandomForestClassifier")
            ),  
      autoSave = FALSE
)
googleModelEval = googleModel$evaluate()
library(xtable)
print(xtable(googleModel$features()[1:5,c("idx","feature")]), type='html', comment=F)
idx feature
1 0 dateToDouble(date) not in range (1.2633156E+12, 1.279728E+12)
2 1 close >= 550.6225
3 2 close_sliding.max >= 590.175
4 3 derivativeY(close_sliding) contains 2.23
5 4 maxSlopeFirstHalf(close_sliding) >= 15.479999999999961 
e=googleModel$evaluate()$summary
## === Detailed Accuracy By Class ===
##                                                                                      
## Class           TP Rate   FP Rate   Precision   Recall   F-Measure   ROC Area   Gini 
##                                                                                      
## true            0.821     0.071     0.958       0.821    0.885       0.962      0.923
## false           0.929     0.179     0.722       0.929    0.813       0.962      0.923
## Weighted Avg.   0.857     0.107     0.88        0.857    0.861       0.962      0.923
##
Now let's enable a deep feature search using an advanced feature search with pairs. 
googleModelAdvanced = learn(projectName = "googleStockAdvanced",
    trainData = googleTrainTest[[1]],
    testData = googleTrainTest[[2]],
    target = "happy",
        featureGenerationCtrl = featureGenerationControl(
                    featureSearchMode = "ADVANCED_WITH_PAIRS",
                    maxFeaturesCount = 50,
                    maxFeatureDuration=5
        ),
      modelBuildingCtrl = modelBuildingControl(
                algorithmsWhiteList = list("RRandomForestClassifier")
    ),
    autoSave = FALSE
)
print(xtable(googleModelAdvanced$features()[1:1,c("idx","feature")]), type='html', comment=F)
idx feature
1 0 average(derivativeY(close_sliding).drop(criticalDay)) < -0.04053124999999937 
e=googleModelAdvanced$evaluate()$summary
## === Detailed Accuracy By Class ===
##                                                                                     
## Class           TP Rate   FP Rate   Precision   Recall   F-Measure   ROC Area   Gini
##                                                                                     
## true            1         0         1           1        1           1          1   
## false           1         0         1           1        1           1          1   
## Weighted Avg.   1         0         1           1        1           1          1   
##



Example 10 - Deep Feature Search Complex Sum


Goal: Complex Sum

Target = (f_1 * Math.log(1.0 + f_1) + f_2 + f_3 + f_4) / 5
Noise = values(f_5 -> f_7) noise random int in 1 to 100

complexSum = getData("complexSum")
print(xtable(head(complexSum,n=5)), type='html', comment=F)
f_0 f_1 f_2 f_3 f_4 f_5 f_6 f_7 tgt
1 31 22 39 57 68 55 6 83 52.24
2 6 1 94 66 66 12 3 53 46.03
3 8 35 33 16 4 72 55 82 16.33
4 21 3 8 43 26 87 85 0 21.22
5 56 97 11 45 35 98 67 4 69.55 
complexSumModel = learn(projectName = "complexSum",
        trainData = complexSum,
        target = "tgt",
                featureGenerationCtrl = featureGenerationControl(
                        maxFeaturesCount = 100,
                        maxFeatureDuration= 5
                ),
                modelBuildingCtrl = modelBuildingControl(
                        algorithmsWhiteList = list("RandomForestRegressor")
                ),
        autoSave = FALSE
    )
complexSumModel$evaluate()$evaluation$rootMeanSquaredError
## [1] 7.260662

complexSumAdvancedModel = learn(
                    projectName = "complexSumAdvanced",
          trainData = complexSum,
          target = "tgt",
                    featureGenerationCtrl = featureGenerationControl(
                                featureSearchMode = "DIG_DEEP",
                                maxFeaturesCount = 100,
                                maxFeatureDuration=5
                    ),
                                modelBuildingCtrl = modelBuildingControl(
                                algorithmsWhiteList = list("RandomForestRegressor")
                    ),
          autoSave = FALSE
        )
library(xtable)
print(xtable(complexSumAdvancedModel$features()[1:5,c("idx","feature")]), type='html', comment=F)
idx feature
1 0 rightSlantedWeightedAverage(average(f_3, f_4), pow(f_0, sigmoid(cbrt(f_1)))) >= 46.6919635520674
2 1 pow(sin(log10(f_0)), rightSlantedWeightedAverage(f_3, f_1)) < 0.12104896222206225
3 2 sigmoid(leftSlantedWeightedAverage(leftSlantedGeometricMean(f_0, f_1), average(f_3, f_4))) != 1.0
4 3 leftSlantedGeometricMean(f_0, f_1) >= 46.553181844068064
5 4 leftSlantedWeightedAverage(leftSlantedGeometricMean(f_0, f_1), average(f_3, f_4)) < 43.848948600591235 
complexSumAdvancedModel$evaluate()$evaluation$rootMeanSquaredError
## [1] 2.539253
